bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Information
bioghist.p: Irish born American author; Brigadier General in the Union army; best known for his humorous description of Civil War events in "The Life and Adventures...of Private Miles O'Reilly."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: The collection contains manuscripts of two poems by Halpine, six letters from him and a drawing.

did.unittitle: Printed poem beginning with her charming looks...on the verso of which is hand written the poem We are coming Father Abrahamby James Sloan Gibbons 1863 Mar 25
Charles G. Halpine to George Washington Cullum 1863 Nov 26

scopecontent.p: Reports on "Private Miles," the fictitious army private he created, and on an interview with President Abraham Lincoln; notes that a report on the latter will be in Saturday's Herald. Includes the poem Nora Creina.

did.unittitle: Charles G. Halpine to Charles Nordhoff 1864 Apr 7

scopecontent.p: Asks Nordhoff to review the appended poem titled April 20th '64and signed "Miles O'Reilly." Also asks Nordhoff to show the poem to William Cullen Bryant for his opinion.

did.unittitle: Charles G. Halpine to George Washington Cullum 1864 Apr 21

scopecontent.p: Reports on information regarding General Ulysses Grant. Offers high praise for General Henry W. Halleck, suggesting he could have been Democratic nominee for President. Refers to his own resignation and new career with a law firm.

did.unittitle: Charles G. Halpine to Douglas Taylor 1867 Feb 21
did.physloc: original in Poems of Charles G. Halpine

scopecontent.p: Confirms appointment. Insists on being assessed his share of expenses. Mentions a Mr. Fowler

did.unittitle: Charles G. Halpine to Salmon P. Chase 1868 Apr 1

scopecontent.p: Urges Chase to seek the Democratic nomination for President in 1868 in the moderate conservative wing, to oppose George Pendleton, who had been the Democratic vice-presidential nominee in 1864.

did.unittitle: Charles G. Halpine to John M. Savage 1868 Jul 22

scopecontent.p: Asks employment for a Thomas Molony, a "Fenian Refugee."
Drawing from a photograph showing Halpine in the uniform of his literary character "Private Miles O'Reilly."
